occurrences.line_text: May you in heauen immortall guerdon gaine
For so great trauell, as you doe sustaine:
That same is it, which fought for you this day.
Then wote you, Sir, that in this Church hereby,
That shall I vnto you (quoth he) bewray;
That it to such a streight mote you constraine)
Yet let me you of courtesie request,
Of vertue, which with you doth there remaine,
Right so from you all goodly vertues well
Into the rest, which round about you ring,
Faire Lords and Ladies, which about you dwell,
Now tell, if please you, of the good successe,
That shall you most renowmed make for euermore.
That you into such perils presently doth call?
Now God you speed (quoth then Sir Artegall)
To all, that passe. That shall you glory gaine
I leaue to you, for aye me to disgrace
The which shal nought to you but foule dishonor yearne.
What haps to day to me, to morrow may to you.
Betwixt you two began this strife and sterne vprore.
That shall I sooth (said he) to you declare.
For what he spake, for you he spake it, Dame;
Please it you Ladie, to vs to aread,
To driue you so on foot vnfit to tread,
To you I will not feare it to relate.
To loue of armes, which in you doth aspire,
I had, you to reward with greater dignitie.
That thankfull guerdon may to you repay.
Faire Lady let it not you seeme disgrace,
What be you wofull Dame, which thus lament,
Nathlesse (quoth he) if need doe not you bynd,
Lo this my cause of griefe to you appeares;
Lo how good fortune doth to you present
Hath you thus long away from me bereft?
And you faire sonne, which here thus long now lie
And I likewise in vaine doe salues to you applie.
For that beastes teeth, which wounded you tofore,
The best (sayd he) that I can you aduize,
So shall you soone repaire your present euill plight.
I must a while forbeare to you to tell;
The wretch, that hyr'd you to this wicked deed.
That pride doe not to tyranny you lift;
Least if men you of cruelty accuse,
He from you take that chiefedome, which ye doe abuse.
But cruelty and hardnesse from you chace,
And from you turne the loue of men to hate.
And to the Prince thus sayd; See you Sir Knight,
That haue with treason thralled vnto you
Or else abide the death, that hard before you stands.
But tell me Lady, wherefore doe you beare
This bottle thus before you with such toile,
Whether I shall you leaue, or from these villaines lose.
Yet no lesse thankes to you for your good will.
Of faire Serena, who as earst you heard,
Shall chargefull be, or chaunge to you at all;
You well reward, and golden guerdon giue,
That may perhaps you better much withall,
And in this quiet make you safer liue.
Therfore do you my rimes keep better measure,
Like a young Squire, in loues and lusty-hed
Young knight, what euer that dost armes professe,
For this young Prince, when first to armes he fell;
Whom still she fed, whiles they were weake & young,
Of tall young men, all hable armes to sownd,
And them before, the fry of children young
Great ioy was made that day of young and old,
And worse and worse young Orphane be thy paine,
But young Perissa was of other mind,
Her daintie paps; which like young fruit in May
And those with which th'EubÃ¦an young man wan
Beside his head there sate a faire young man,
From which young Hectors bloud by cruell Greekes was spilt.
Madan was young, vnmeet the rule of sway,
He left two sonnes, too young to rule aright,
Whilst they were young, Cassibalane their Eme
The young man sleeping by her, seemd to bee
Emongst his young ones shall diuide with bountyhed.
Of the young Damzell sunke, that great desire
About her selfe she dight, that the young Mayd
And oft young birds, which he had taught to sing
To seeke young men, to quench her flaming thurst,
Thereat displeasd they were, till that young Squire
Till that young Squire him reared from below;
That fierce young mans vnruly maistery;
Far off aspyde a young man, the which fled
But that young Knight, which through her gentle deed
And in his hand a tall young oake he bore,
Her captiue louers friend, young Placidas:
I boldly thought (so young mens thoughts are bold)
On either side of her, two young men stood,
And their young bloodie babe to him gan tell;
Vnto this shame, and my young hope subuert,
Calidore sees young Tristram slay
A tall young man from thence not farre away,
To take me vp (as this young man did see)
So passed we, till this young man vs met,
Full glad and ioyous then young Tristram grew,
But lou'd this fresh young Knight, who dwelt her ny,
Of his young charge, whereof he skilled nought:
Prince Arthur and young Timias, which met
A faire young Mayden, full of comely glee;
That this young Mayd, whom chance to her presents
Her younger sister, that Speranza hight,
The younger daughter of Chrysogonee,
Hate was the elder, Loue the younger brother;
Yet was the younger stronger in his state
Then did my younger brother Amidas
So hauing sayd, the younger did ensew;
Then Artegall thus to the younger sayd;
Of one bad sire, whose youngest is Sans ioy,
The eldest did against the youngest goe,
But he that lou'd the youngest, was Sans-loy,
The second Dyamond, the youngest Triamond.
That is berobbed of her youngling dere,
More deare vnto their God, then you[n]glings to their dam.
But that same younker soone was ouer throwne,
And perill without show: therefore your stroke
Add faith vnto your force, and be not faint:
Who see your vanquisht foes before you lye:
And proou'd your strength on a strong enimie,
Your first aduenture: many such I pray,
And well I wote, that of your later fight
Then with the Sunne take Sir, your timely rest,
Therefore with me ye may take vp your In
Your owne deare sake forst me at first to leaue
Fly to your faith for succour and sure ayde:
Loue of your selfe, she said, and deare constraint
Assure your selfe, it fell not all to ground;
I deeme your loue, and hold me to you bound;
Ne let vaine feares procure your needlesse smart,
Where cause is none, but to your rest depart.
Come see, where your false Lady doth her honour staine.
And to your mighty will. Her humblesse low
And said, Deare dame, your suddein ouerthrow
And tell, both who ye be, and who that tooke your part.
Hath now made thrall to your commandement,
And fortune false betraide me to your powre,
That may restore you to your wonted well?
For since mine eye your ioyous sight did mis,
Farre be it from your thought, and fro my will,
Haue vowd you to defend. Now then your plaint appease.
Vnder your beames I will me safely shrowd,
Let now abate the terror of your might,
Couering your foe with cloud of deadly night,
Well may I weene, your griefe is wondrous great;
Whiles thus I heare you of your sorrowes treat.
For to vnfold the anguish of your hart:
Or that your wisedome will direct my thought,
Or that your prowesse can me yield reliefe:
The forlorne Maiden, whom your eyes haue seene
Where haue you left your Lord, that could so well you tosse?
For till I haue acquit your captiue knight,
Assure your selfe, I will you not forsake.
Therefore, deare Sir, your mightie powres assay.
That with your worth the world amazed make,
But sith the heauens, and your faire handeling
Your fortune maister eke with gouerning,
That of your selfe ye thus berobbed arre,
And this misseeming hew your manly looks doth marre?
Loe where your foe lyes stretcht in monstrous length,
And loe that wicked woman in your sight,
The roote of all your care, and wretched plight,
Now in your powre, to let her liue, or dye.
Ensample make of him your haplesse ioy,
O foolish men, why haste ye to your owne decay?
Then Vna thus; But she your sister deare;
And you good Sir, I wote that of your toyle,
Iread you rest, and to your bowres recoyle.
Therefore henceforth be at your keeping well,
And euer ready for your foeman fell.
And striue your excellent selfe to excell;
Vnto you bring, to ease you of your misery.
From first to last in your late enterprise,
As that your daughter can ye well aduize,
Withhold, O soueraine Prince, your hasty hond
But if your selfe, Sir knight, ye faultie find,
Now strike your sailes ye iolly Mariners,
That feeble eyes your glory may behold,
And great atchieu'ments great your selfe to make,
Vouchsafe to stay your steed for humble misers sake.
And marre the blossome of your beautie bright:
For thy appease your griefe and heauie plight,
And tell the cause of your conceiued paine.
Now therefore Ladie, rise out of your paine,
And see the saluing of your blotted name.
Which on your shield is set for ornament:
That decks and armes your shield with faire defence:
Your court'sie takes on you anothers due offence.
For sith I know your goodly gouernaunce,
And that deare Crosse vpon your shield deuizd,
For which enrolled is your glorious name
Where you a Saint with Saints your seat haue wonne:
But wretched we, where ye haue left your marke,
Well mote yee thee, as well can wish your thought,
Thus fowle to hasten your vntimely date;
Haue not all seized on your frozen hart,
Let one word fall that may your griefe vnfold,
And tell the secret of your mortall smart;
The bitter pangs, that doth your heart infest.
That I may cast to compasse your reliefe,
Or die with you in sorrow, and partake your griefe.
And of your ignorance great maruell make,
Or fell Erinnys, in your noble harts
And stird you vp to worke your wilfull smarts?
Hold, ï¿½ deare Lord, hold your dead-doing hand,
Then loud he cryde, I am your humble thrall.
Giue no ods to your foes, but do puruay
Your selfe of sword before that bloudy day:
Do arme your selfe against that day, them to confound.
That shall I shortly purchase to your hond:
Till this mad man, whom your victorious might
But all your hurts may soone through te[m]perance be easd.
Your cruell eyes endure so pitteous sight,
To shed your liues on ground? wo worth the man,
Your yron brestes, or pittie could find place,
Withhold your bloudie hands from battell fierce,
Both yeeld, to stay your deadly strife a space.
Your selfe his prowesse prou'd & found him fiers & bold.
Ne blame your honour with so shamefull vaunt
And vnto battell doe your selues addresse;
Or ought that else your honour might maintaine,
And by your powre protect his feeble cace.
To wreake your wrath on this dead seeming knight,
Mote ought allay the storme of your despight,
Not to debate the chalenge of your right,
To weet why on your shield so goodly scord
O how great wonder would your thoughts deuoure,
And infinite desire into your spirite poure!
But by your wondrous worth and warlike feat
But were your will, her sold to entertaine,
Mote stead you much your purpose to subdew.
If that your liues ye loue, as meete ye should;
Fly fast, and saue your selues from neare decay,
And your faire beautie do with sadnesse spill?
Or doen you loue, or doen you lacke your will?
And in your selfe do not the same aduise?
Faire Damzell, seemeth, by your troubled cheare,
That in the secret of your hart close lyes,
She is the fountaine of your modestee;
Your stubborne hart t'affect with fraile infirmity.
To which when she your courage hath inclind
She will embosome deeper in your mind,
And for your ruine at the last awayt.
Therefore, Sir knight, your ready armes about you throw.
Cannot your glorious pourtraict figure plaine
Your selfe you couet to see pictured,
To weene your wrong by force to iustifie:
Ne to your Lady will I seruice done,
But wreake your wrongs wrought to this knight alone,
Our faulty weaknesse, and your matchlesse might:
Which by her owne law to your lot doth light,
And we your liege men faith vnto you plight.
And chaste desires do nourish in your mind,
Let not her fault your sweet affections marre,
Least that too farre ye haue your sorrow sought:
You and your countrey both I wish welfare,
Your curteous tongue, his prayses to compile,
To slake your wrath, and mollifie your mind,
To slake your wrath, and mollifie your mind,
Another arrow hath your louers hart to hit.
Salue to your sore, yet loue can higher stye,
Or why make ye such Monster of your mind?
To loue the semblant pleasing most your mind,
And yield your heart, whence ye cannot remoue?
Beldame, your words doe worke me litle ease;
More need of leach-craft hath your Damozell,
And sooth, it ought your courage much inflame,
By your good counsell, or bold hardiment,
And to your willes both royalties and Realmes
Subdew, through conquest of your wondrous might,
With this faire flowre your goodly girlonds dight,
That shall embellish more your beautie bright,
And crowne your heades with heauenly coronall,
Of your gay sonne, that giues ye so good ayd
To your disports: ill mote ye bene apayd.
The like that mine, may be your paine another tide.
Your glory set, to chace the saluage beasts,
And ill becomes you with your loftie creasts,
To lurke emongst your Nymphes in secret wize;
And sharply said; Goe Dame, goe seeke your boy,
Vnto your dwelling, ignorant and loth,
In your auengement and dispiteous rage,
Ne ought your burning fury mote abate;
Your zealous hast, till morrow next againe
Which if ye please, to yonder castle turne your gate.
Or ought your goodly patience offend,
The shyning glory of your soueraigne light,
Behold, Sir, how your pitifull complaint
Hath found another partner of your payne:
To turne your course, I would to heare desyre,
Your countrey kin, and you entirely pray
Vnto your patience, ne be ill ypaid;
Cannot employ your most victorious speare
So shall your glory be aduaunced much,
And all faire Ladies magnifie your might,
Your worthy paine shall well reward with guerdon rich.
Your treasure here in some securitie,
Ne priuie be vnto your treasures graue.
And ye faire Ladies, that your kingdomes make
And euer in your noble hart prepense,
Hath outrag'd you, and thrald your gentle make.
Perhaps this hand may helpe to ease your woe,
And wreake your sorrow on your cruell foe,
And wreake your sorrow on your cruell foe,
And said; Sir knight, your cause is nothing lesse,
Then is your sorrow, certes if not more;
Yield you in liew of this your gratious deed?
Your vertue selfe her owne reward shall breed,
Which I your vassall, by your prowesse freed,
Which I your vassall, by your prowesse freed,
And meane of your deliuerance haue beene:
In stead thereof know, that your louing Make,
Hath no lesse griefe endured for your gentle sake.
And ye faire swayns, after your long turmoyle,
Now cease your worke, and at your pleasure play:
Now cease your worke, and at your pleasure play:
Now cease your worke; to morrow is an holy day.
Lo there Sir Paridel, for your desart,
For pitie that ye want a fellow for your ayd.
And I without your perill or your cost,
And I without your perill or your cost,
That as I late aduentured for your sake,
Your selfe for this, my selfe will for you fight,
That she your loue list loue another knight,
Ne do your selfe dislike a whit the more;
I saw him haue your Amoret at will,
That for this Ladie present in your vew,
To ioyne your force, their forces to repell,
And of your gotten spoyle their owne triumph to make.
Since therefore she her selfe is now your ward,
And saue her honour with your ventrous paines;
Till then your challenges ye may prolong;
Ah gentle Scudamour, vnto your grace
What is your owne, that I mote you requite?
That seemeth well to answere to your weede?
That whylome in your minde wont to despise them all.
Hath troubled both your mindes with idle thought,
Fearing least she your loues away should woo,
Relent the rigour of your wrathfull will,
Graunt him your grace, but so that he fulfill
Ne any but your selfe, O dearest dred,
Your high displesure, through misdeeming bred:
That when your pleasure is to deeme aright,
But since ye so desire, your will be donne.
For ill your goddesse seruices are drest
And shame on you, ï¿½ men, which boast your strong
And if he shall through pride your doome vndo,
Vpon your seas, he claym'd as propertie:
Therefore I humbly craue your Maiestie,
But if ye please, that I your cause decide,
And both the liuing Lady claime your right,
Take here your owne, that doth you best beseeme,
Your owne dead Ladies head, to tell abrode your shame.
Your owne dead Ladies head, to tell abrode your shame.
To wreake your wrath on such a carle as hee:
Certes your strife were easie to accord,
Vnto your selfe, said they, we giue our word,
Your brothers land the which the sea hath layd
Vnto your part, and pluckt from his away,
Your right is good (sayd he) and so I deeme,
That what the sea vnto you sent, your own should seeme.
Your brothers threasure, which from him is strayd,
By what right doe you claime to be your owne?
Your right is good (sayd he) and so I deeme,
That what the sea vnto you sent, your own should seeme.
Or haue you lost your selfe, and your discretion,
Or haue you lost your selfe, and your discretion,
As for to lead your selfe vnto your owne decay?
As for to lead your selfe vnto your owne decay?
Your misery, how fell ye in this state.
How Fortune will your ruin'd name repaire,
Can dread of ought your dreadlesse hart withhold,
Doth not your handmayds life at your foot lie?
Doth not your handmayds life at your foot lie?
For such your kind regard, I can but rest your detter.
For such your kind regard, I can but rest your detter.
Which if I might by your good office get,
I to your selfe should rest for euer bound,
My Lord, your Loue, by hard mishap doth lie
Vnto your losse: and now needes will ye sleepe?
To thinke of your nights want, that should yee waking keepe.
That by your change of cheare is easie for to see.
Your aide, to guide me out of errour blind.
Say on (quoth he) the secret of your hart:
Vpon your selues anothers wrong to wreake?
Which was the roote of all, end your reuenge on mee.
But thankt be God, and your good hardiment,
Were not (sayd she) that it should let your pace
Then let not that (said they) stay your intent;
Now rise againe, at this your ioyous sight.
If not, we will it force, maugre your foe,
That your victorious arme will not yet cease,
Assure your selfe, Sir Knight, she shall haue ayd,
Your owne good shield in daungerous dismay?
Your honours stile, that is your warlike shield.
Your honours stile, that is your warlike shield.
To blot your beautie, that vnblemisht is,
And let your fame with falshood be defaced?
But dearer then the[m] both, your faith once plighted hold.
As in your selfe, O soueraine Lady Queene,
Yet so from low to high vplifted is your fame.
That from your selfe I doe this vertue bring,
And to your selfe doe it returne againe:
And doe adorne your Court, where courtesies excell.
Which ye haue had in your late enterprize.
Yet now some hope your words vnto me add.
And keepe your body from the daunger drad:
Then doe your selfe, for dread of shame, forgoe
But saue my life, which lot before your foot doth lay.
I will it graunt, your hopelesse life to saue;
First, that ye better shall your selfe behaue
Whereof befell, what now is in your sight.
Ye dolefull Dame, let not your griefe empeach
For he, that hath your Knight so ill bestad,
Which to your selfe he wrought, & to your loued knight.
Which to your selfe he wrought, & to your loued knight.
Which ye haue gathered to your gentle hart,
Were best deuise for this your louers smart,
To beare this burden on your dainty backe;
My selfe will beare a part, coportion of your packe.
That which your selfe haue earst ared so right?
Doe it disclose, to ease your grieued spright:
If that the cause of this your languishment
Be lacke of children, to supply your place,
That ye will not your wrath vpon him wreake,
Small praise to proue your powre on wight so weake.
For in your selfe your onely helpe doth lie,
For in your selfe your onely helpe doth lie,
To heale your selues, and must proceed alone
From your owne will, to cure your maladie.
From your owne will, to cure your maladie.
First learne your outward sences to refraine
Your eies, your eares, your tongue, your talk restraine
Your eies, your eares, your tongue, your talk restraine
Your eies, your eares, your tongue, your talk restraine
Your eies, your eares, your tongue, your talk restraine
Abstaine from pleasure, and restraine your will,
Vse scanted diet, and forbeare your fill,
So shall you soone repaire your present euill plight.
And sayd; Now sure ye well haue earn'd your meed,
The which I earst aduentur'd for your sake.
And where is eke your friend, which halfe it ought?
And th'hearts of men, as your eternall dowre,
Deliuered hath into your hands by gift;
That all your other praises will deface,
These two, vnworthy of your wretched bands;
And now your crime with cruelty pursew.
Abide, and from them lay your loathly hands;
And eeke this wallet at your backe arreare,
Now Lady sith your fortunes thus dispose,
Vnto your selfe I freely leaue to chose,
Yet no lesse thankes to you for your good will.
That certes I your happinesse enuie,
In this small plot of your dominion,
I may here with your selfe some small repose obtaine.
For your meane food shall be my daily feast,
And this your cabin both my bowre and hall.
And thus bespake; Sir knight, your bounteous proffe[r]
Be it your owne: our rudenesse to your selfe aread.
Be it your owne: our rudenesse to your selfe aread.
That yond same is your daughter sure, which yet doth liue.
To youre faire selues a faire ensample frame,
The conquest yours, I yours, the shield, and glory yours.
The conquest yours, I yours, the shield, and glory yours.
The conquest yours, I yours, the shield, and glory yours.
For thy, faire Sir, yours be the Damozell,
Sweare she is yours, and stirre vp bloudie frayes,
This now be yours, God send you better gaine.
But yours the waift by high prerogatiue.
So Amidas, the land was yours first hight,
And so the threasure yours is Bracidas by right.
Yeeld for amends my selfe yours euermore,
Ne yours conceiue, ne but by tokens speake:
Both for her noble bloud, and for her tender youth.
They in compassion of her tender youth,
A gentle youth, his dearely loued Squire
Who earst in flowres of freshest youth was clad.
In vertuous lore to traine his tender youth,
The antique world, in his first flowring youth,
The weary Britons, whose war-hable youth
The bud of youth to blossome faire began,
With all the warlike youth of Troians bloud,
By which fraile youth is oft to follie led,
The hot-spurre youth so scorning to be crost,
Dame Venus sonne that tameth stubborne youth
That whilome in his youth had bene a Knight,
But ere he came in place, that youth had kild
A goodly youth of amiable grace,
To whom then thus the noble youth; May be
That in his youth had beene of mickle might,
When pride of youth forth pricked my desire,
From natiue home, and spent my youth in vaine,
The warlike youthes on dayntie couches layd,
Abroad thy fresh youthes fairest flowre, but lose
With those two gentle youthes, which him did guide,
Layes of sweete loue and youthes delightfull heat:
Who whylome was in his youthes freshest flowre
The youthfull knight could not for ought be staide,
Her mate he was a iollie youthfull knight,
And hard to finde, that heat of youthfull spright
